utterances: This year, though, the Bison are 9 and 1.

Forty years ago, the Middle East was at war.

Each side calls the war by the holiday it fell on in 1973.
To Arabs, it was the Ramadan War; to Israelis, it was Yom Kippur War.
Both Egypt and Israel suffered heavy casualties, and both achieved battlefield victories.
And the result was sufficiently ambiguous.
Neither side had suffered a humiliating defeat that a few years later, Egypt and Israel could make peace, and Egypt could regain the Sinai Peninsula.
With 40 years of hindsight and research, our sense of the October 1973 war continues to evolve.
And today, we're going to hear an Israeli perspective.
Ehud Yaari is a commentator for Israel's Channel 2 television.
He's also a fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy in Washington.
And he joins us from Jerusalem.
And first, Ehud Yaari, how do recently declassified documents alter your view of what happened in the Yom Kippur War?

The dismal economy and high unemployment have dogged Schroeder and split his SPD party.
Traditional party faithful were unhappy with cuts to health and welfare benefits that aim to improve the economy and business climate.

But the SPD also lost in North Rhine-Westphalia because of voters like 44-year-old restaurant owner Klaus Becker(ph), who thinks Schroeder's painful economic policies will help in the long run, but his party won't.
It's not bye-bye, Schroeder.
It's bye-bye, SPD.
The problem is, Schroeder is a good man, but his party is the wrong one.
German media is skeptical about the future success of either one.
Schroeder scraped together a re-election victory two years ago by opposing the US-led invasion of Iraq.
Leading news magazine Der Spiegel today writes that President George Bush could now invade France, and Schroeder would still lose re-election.
Emily Harris, NPR News, Dusseldorf.
And now, a story about consolidation in the media business.
No, it's not Rupert Murdock's attempt to take over the Wall Street Journal.
It's about two papers in Charleston West Virginia where the U.S Justice Department wants to reverse a merger.
Here's Greg Collard of West Virginia Public Broadcasting.
The Charleston Gazette is known for it's investigative journalism.
Because it sometimes is the paper people love to hate.
Managing editor, Patty Tompkins has emphasized this during her 25 years at the Gazette.
We're one of the few papers - certainly the only one in the state, but one of the few papers in the country who still believes them watchdog journalism.
Now, the Gazette finds itself under investigation.
Three years ago, the Gazette paid $55 million to purchase its competitor, the conservative-leaning Charleston Daily Mail from Media NewsGroup of Denver.
Last week, the Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against The Daily Gazette Company, claiming it engaged in business practices designed to destroy the Daily Mail.
Former Daily Mail city editor Jeff Morris left the paper in 2005.
He says, for example, the Gazette didn't allow his paper to replace newsroom staff who resigned.
At one point, some of the staff members even stuffed some dummies with pillows and had some cardboard cutouts and put those in the chairs to fill some of those empty desks.
The lawsuit says the Gazette also stopped deliveries for thousands of Daily Mail customers and trying to persuade Daily Mail subscribers to switch to the Gazette.
This case is unusual in several ways.
The Bush Justice Department averages about 133 merger investigations a year, but only about seven lead to a federal civil lawsuit.
No one from the government would comment on tape, sighting pending litigation.
California attorney Denise Diaz worked in the Antitrust Division under Clinton and the first Bush administration and now publishes an online newsletter dedicated to antitrust issues.
Just strictly from an actual(ph) perspective, it looks like they got a meritorious case to make and it's going to be a difficult one.
Because unwinding a deal is not an easy thing to do.
It's one of the most difficult things you can do when the merger area.
When the McClatchy Company bought Knight Ridder last year, it ended up with both of daily newspapers in Minneapolis-St.
Paul.
The Justice Department approved that deal if McClatchy sold one of the papers.
Newspapers have been allowed to buy their competitors and shut them down.
But in those cases, no one else was willing to buy the papers.
That's not the case here.
The lawsuit says, an unnamed third party offered to buy the Daily Mail for the same price as the Gazette paid.
Gazette publisher Elizabeth Chilton won't address specifics of the case.
We feel we're right and have done nothing wrong.
I have no comment on it, because it's in the judicial system now.
It's in it the courts.

The Department of Justice says it's trying to preserve newspaper competition in Charleston, but the fear is this lawsuit will undermine one of the declining number of family-owned newspapers left in America.
For NPR News, Greg Collard in Charleston, West Virginia.

Incumbent Senator Joe Lieberman of Connecticut, who lost the Democratic Party primary in August, has pulled way ahead of the party nominee Ned Lamont.

He and Lamont will face each other Monday night in a final televised debate.
And the Associated Press has published data from the Census Bureau that political analysts will be sure to chew over.
It turns out that between the years 2000 and 2005, congressional districts held by Republicans added a total of about three million immigrants to their population.
This is nearly twice as many as the number of immigrants who settled in Democratic districts.
The newcomers include both legal and undocumented residents, and this brings us to our next story.
A city in Southern California has become the latest in a small number of communities across the country to crack down on landlords who rent to illegal immigrants.
The Escondido City Council has passed a measure that slaps fines on landlords who rent to undocumented immigrants and could send repeat offenders to jail.
From member station KPBS in San Diego, Amy Isackson has the story.

So far in our series on Philadelphia's troubled school system, we have heard about the enormous challenges of inadequate financing, budget cuts and poverty - obstacles all of America's largest, urban school districts are grappling with.
Today, we look at what one camp in the school reform movement sees as a key solution: charter schools.
These are taxpayer-funded schools typically managed by private nonprofits.
In Philadelphia, charter enrollment has soared.
But are charters there doing any better than their regular, public counterparts?
NPR's Eric Westervelt takes a look.
